I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) will implement phase 1 of 
the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience (PPCR) in Papua New Guinea (PNG) and Tonga. It will 
build  on  existing  climate  change  vulnerability  assessments,  prioritize  projects  for  climate 
resilience,  conduct  training  for  key  infrastructure  ministries  on  climate  change  adaptation 
mainstreaming, and prepare two phase 2 investment proposals (Strategic Program for Climate 
Resilience) for increasing the climate resilience of infrastructure and other development projects 
in PNG and Tonga (Supplementary Annex A).1 
2.  The TA has been developed in consultation with the governments of PNG and Tonga. 
Both governments submitted, with Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) assistance, PPCR phase 1 
funding proposals to the PPCR subcommittee in September 2010. In October 2010, funding 
was approved in the amount of $750,000 for phase 1 of the PPCR with $500,000 for PNG and 
$250,000 for Tonga, respectively (Supplementary Appendix B). The TA meets priority needs of 
PNG and Tonga and is consistent with ADB’s strategic focus on promoting climate resilient 
infrastructure  investments  through  adaptation.  The  TA  is  also  in  line  with  ADB’s  Pacific 
Approach, 2010–20152; the Pacific Regional Operational Business Plan3 and the Pacific Climate 
Change Implementation Plan.4 The TA will implement the PNG and Tonga proposals, financed 
by PPCR, and build on ADB’s investment priorities in the infrastructure sector in both countries.5 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Climate change impacts. PNG and Tonga are highly vulnerable to the adverse impacts 
of climate change. PNG is sensitive to natural hazards such as coastal flooding, inland flooding, 
landslides, and drought, which have severe impacts on agriculture, economic (transport and 
flood  control)  and  social  infrastructure.  PNG’s  Climate  Compatible  Development  Strategy 
(CCDS)6 highlights the significant risks posed by climate change to the environment, economy, 
and population, including those resulting from natural disasters. These climate change impacts 
place a further burden on already significant development challenges in PNG.  
 
4.  Tonga, an archipelago of 170 small islands, is prone to tsunamis, tropical cyclones, and 
floods. Tonga’s Initial National Communication7 identified that all sectors are likely to be affected 
by climate change, with key impacts on agricultural production, coastal resources, and social 
infrastructure. Consequently, the socioeconomic impacts of climate change in Tonga are also 
likely to be significant. The TA will help enhance national capacity to manage climate change 
impacts, which both countries are facing. 
 
5.  Climate change mainstreaming. In both PNG and Tonga, the value of mainstreaming 
climate change adaptation and disaster risk management into core development planning has 
been recognized at the national level in policy documents such as PNG’s CCDS and Tonga’s 
Joint National Action Plan on Climate Adaptation and Natural Disaster Risk Management 2010–
2015. These documents provide a strong strategic foundation for efforts to integrate climate

face significant challenges to operationalize adaptation strategies into sectoral planning and

6.  In PNG, the implementation of CCDS has been constrained by limited awareness of 
successful  approaches,  lack  of  access  to  technical  training  and  knowledge  products,  and 
inadequate finance have constrained integration of climate risk management into infrastructure 
planning and project design.  
 
7.  In Tonga, similar constraints in awareness, finance and technical capacity exist for 
mainstreaming climate change adaptation. Beyond the Ministry of Environment and Climate 
Change, limited attention has been given to climate risk concerns in national and sector policy 
planning and budgeting and project design. Efforts were initiated to incorporate climate change 
and disaster risk management considerations with cabinet endorsement of the Joint National 
Action Plan on Climate Adaptation and Disaster Risk Management, 2010–2015. Early progress 
includes  ensuring  the  incorporation  of  disaster  risk  management  in  local  building  codes. 
However, implementation is slow as there is a lack of access to technical training, knowledge 
products and capacity building. Climate risk management is yet to be fully integrated into policy, 
planning, and budgetary processes.  
 
8.  During TA fact finding missions, a stocktake of government and development partner 
climate change adaptation activities by the respective governments was undertaken in both 
countries. This revealed that a coordinated development partners’ approach to climate change 
adaptation mainstreaming is needed. Such an approach must be supported at the country level, 
with strong engagement from coordinating and sector agencies, local government and civil 
society stakeholders.  
 
9.  Climate-resilient infrastructure, especially transport infrastructure, is essential for efficient 
flow of produce to markets and for the provision of essential services and consumer goods to 
rural and urban communities. Building climate resilient infrastructure will help each of the two 
countries in their poverty reduction, education and health programs in accordance with the 
Millennium  Development  Goals.  Properly  planned,  appropriately  designed  and  prioritized 
rehabilitation and maintenance of climate-resilient infrastructure will underpin economic and 
social development.  In both PNG and Tonga, significant infrastructure investments have been 
planned, and risks to infrastructure due to climate change have been identified in key national 
documents. 
 
10.  In view of the above, the need to enhance institutional capacity for mainstreaming 
climate  change  resilience  into  policies,  plans,  and  operational  activities  of  the  ministries 
responsible for infrastructure is evident. Civil society and private sector engagement and gender 
considerations  in  infrastructure  resilience-building  must  also  be  strengthened  given  the 
important roles of these actors in climate resilience building.  Strengthening institutional capacity 
will in turn facilitate the flow of investment funds for climate-resilient infrastructure. The TA will 
raise awareness and provide critical technical assistance and training for PNG and Tonga 
officials to mainstream climate change adaptation and disaster risk management considerations 
at the operational level.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.   The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  climate-resilient  infrastructure  development  planning, 
budgeting, and implementation by the PNG and Tonga governments. The outcome will be two 
Strategic Programs for Climate Change Resilience (SPCRs) for 2011–2015 for investments in 
PNG and Tonga, respectively, agreed by the two governments and approved by the PPCR sub- 
committee. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.   Two investment programs (SPCRs for PPCR phase 2) for PNG and Tonga will be 
developed  to  mainstream  climate  resilience  in  national  development  planning  and 
implementation based on updated assessments of climate change vulnerabilities in key sectors 
and/or regions. These assessments will take account of earlier vulnerability assessments that 
identified sector and region-specific priorities. In PNG, this has occurred as part of CCDS 
formulation. In Tonga, the National Adaptation Plan of Action will, with assistance under the TA, 
help to incorporate climate change resilience into infrastructure planning and development. The 
SPCRs  will  identify  infrastructure  projects that  can  be  targeted for  investments,  based  on 
current national development priorities and the status of government and development partners’ 
investment pipelines. 
  
13.   Concurrently, a capacity building program (CBP) will be developed for both countries. 
This will commence during phase 1 of PPCR and continue during phase 2. Training programs 
for key ministries will be initiated to facilitate integration of climate change resilience in planning, 
budgetary systems, financial allocations and reporting mechanisms. The CBP will be based on 
a needs assessment and development of approaches for effective involvement of the private 
sector  and  civil  society  in  climate-resilient  development.  Government  and  nongovernment 
engagement  will  be  facilitated  by  developing  and  disseminating  information  products  and 
identifying  specific  opportunities  for  participation.  Information  products  on  climate  change 
scenarios,  vulnerability  assessments,  opportunities  for  private  sector  engagement,  and 
incorporating gender concerns in climate change adaptation are priority areas for the TA. A 
web-based platform will also be developed to facilitate information generation, dissemination, 
and implementation monitoring.  
 
14.   The  TA  will  have  two  main  outputs:  (i)  capacity  building  (comprising  training  and 
awareness raising) of key government agencies, private sector and civil society focused on 
incorporating  climate  change  adaptation  in  national  and  infrastructure  sector  planning, 
budgeting and design; and (ii) preparation of two investment programs (SPCRs for PPCR phase 
2) which will identify investment options for enhancing climate resilience in key infrastructure 
sector programs and projects, endorsed by stakeholders, with cost estimates and indicators for 
monitoring progress. 
 
15.   In each country, the TA will: (i) review available data and analyses on climate change 
vulnerability,  (ii)  develop  a  set  of  strategic-level  climate  change  scenarios  and  a  selected 
number of vulnerability assessments, (iii) undertake capacity-needs assessment for involvement 
of private sector and civil society, and  prepare information products targeted at both groups, (iv) 
develop  approaches  for  integrating  gender  concerns  into  climate  change  adaptation  pilot 
projects, (v) identify and operationalize opportunities for private sector engagement in climate

4   
 
change adaptation, (vi)  prepare national guidelines and best practices manual for integration of 
climate change factors into infrastructure planning, and (vii) identify financial requirements for 
investment projects for inclusion in the SPCR. The results of these activities will be used to (i) 
prepare SPCRs with investment proposals for enhancing climate resilience of infrastructure 
projects,  (ii)  a  capacity-building  program;  and  (iii)  a  web-based  monitoring  platform  for 
dissemination of information products, and monitoring of programs. The web-based information 
will include vulnerability assessments, lessons learned, progress reports, and links to regional 
and  global  climate  change  adaptation  websites.  The  information  will  be  accessible  to  all 
stakeholders.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost the equivalent of $825,000, $750,000 of which will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Strategic  Climate  Fund  administered  by  ADB8.  Of  the 
$750,000, $500,000 will be allocated to PNG and $250,000 to Tonga. The remaining $75,000 
will be contributed in kind by the governments of PNG ($50,000) and Tonga ($25,000), and both 
countries will finalize their in-kind contribution before the TA implementation. The detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. The expected total value of investment under 
phase 2 SPCR for both countries is estimated to be $40 million consisting of $25 million–$30 
million for PNG and $10 million–$15 million for Tonga. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB’s Pacific Department will be the executing agency for the TA, which will begin 
implementation in June 2011 and be completed by February 2012. Implementing agencies will 
be the PPCR focal agencies in the two countries.9 To ensure whole-of-government engagement 
and coordination, the implementing agencies will consult relevant government departments 
through existing interdepartmental committees. The governments will also consult with private 
sector, civil society and development partners through existing consultation forums. At the 
regional level, the Pacific Department and the Climate Investment Fund (CIF) will facilitate 
regional information sharing through the Pacific PPCR, in particular the regionwide activities 
component (Supplementary Appendix A). A letter of no-objection will be obtained from both 
participating countries prior to commencing or financing activities under the TA in the territory of 
the participating country.  
 
18.  TA  consultations  will  include  governments  (including  local  government  where  their 
responsibilities  intersect  with  climate  change  adaptation mainstreaming  efforts), the  private 
sector  and  civil  society  stakeholders.  Lessons  learned  on  climate  change  adaptation 
mainstreaming and related capacity-building will be shared with: (i) other government agencies 
and  stakeholders  in  PNG  and Tonga;  and (ii)  other  Pacific  developing member countries, 
including through regional organizations processes and the Pacific PPCR region wide activities 
component.  
 
19.  The TA will require international (13.5 person-months) and national (10 person-months) 
consulting services. Consultants will be recruited through a firm using quality and cost-based 
selection  (80:20)  with  a  simplified  technical  proposal.  Two  country  climate  change

IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 to be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Strategic  Climate  Fund  for  Strengthening  Climate  Risk  and  Resilience 
Capacity of Pacific Developing Member Countries, phase 1 and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANT 
 
1.  All team members will be required to undertake a comprehensive review of relevant 
documents including development partner reports, Asian Development Bank (ADB) country 
programming  documents  (country  partnership  strategies  and  country  operations  business 
plans),  workshop  proceedings,  Climate  Investment  Fund  (CIF)  Pilot  Program  for  Climate 
Resilience (PPCR) guidelines, and national strategies and action plans to develop the Strategic 
Program for Climate Resilience (SPCR).  
 
A.  Team Leader (international, 4.5 person-months over 9-month period) 
  
2.  The consultant will have at least 10 years experience in climate change-related work 
with a relevant master’s degree or higher in civil engineering, infrastructure planning, hydrology, 
climate science or a related area. The consultant will have considerable experience as team 
leader and background that includes extensive experience in assisting government institutions. 
Other requirements are country experience and the ability to work effectively with government 
representatives (national and local levels), development partners, and other stakeholders and to 
report effectively in strategic consultations and written reports. The team leader will also be 
responsible  for  procurement  of  materials  and  equipment,  organization  and  conduct  of 
workshops, and surveys, in consultation with the team members and the governments as 
appropriate. 
 
3.  The team leader will lead the project team to ensure timely delivery of regional capacity 
development  technical  assistance  (TA)  outputs  according  to  an  agreed  timetable.  An 
international consultant will be engaged for 4.5 person-months over a 9-month period to work 
(from home, in the field, and in ADB headquarters) with national consultants in Papua New 
Guinea (PNG) and Tonga, and the ADB Pacific Climate Change Team to help implement the 
PPCR phase 1 program, and work with the national and international project team members to 
deliver the SPCR, for the ADB-led components of the Pacific PPCR.  The team leader will be 
responsible for the overall design of the SPCR, lead capacity-building interventions, and provide 
oversight and management of all consultant team members (5 in total, national and international 
consultants). In coordination with the web developer, the team leader may also be required to 
develop  a  detailed  specification  for  the  regional  web-based  platform,  in  line  with  ADB 
information management requirements. 
 
4.  This consultancy will primarily work on two of the four Pacific PPCR components: (i) 
PNG, (ii) Tonga, coordinating as necessary with the development of the region wide activities 
component. The consultant will be required for 50% of the project duration (9 months) and up to 
three visits to both PNG and Tonga. Project initiation visits to ADB headquarters in Manila and 
regular team briefings may also be required. 
 
5.  Specifically, the team leader will do the following: 
 
(i)  Lead PPCR phase 1 activities in PNG and Tonga in close collaboration with the 
PNG and Tonga governments as outlined in the PPCR phase 1 proposals for 
PNG and Tonga. 
(ii)  Lead the preparation of key documents required by ADB and/or the PPCR sub 
committee and CIF administration unit with emphasis on ADB funding modalities 
and  the  SPCR  and  any  other  supporting  documentation  as  required,  in 
accordance with PPCR guidelines.

(iii)  Be  responsible  for  compilation  of  (a)  a  needs  assessment  capacity  building 
report  based  on  inputs  by  team  members  and  initiation  of  capacity  building 
activities in key ministries, sector agencies, and other relevant institutions; and 
(b)  drafting  of  SPCR  with  inputs  from  other  members  of  the  team,  with 
investment proposals for climate-proofing of infrastructure projects, a capacity 
building  program,  and  a  web-based  monitoring  platform  in  accordance  with 
PPCR guidelines. 
(iv)  Develop  and  implement  a  detailed  project  plan  (including  monitoring  and 
evaluation plan) outlining key products and activities that will support drafting the 
SPCR  and  building  in-country  capacity  as  specified  in  the  PPCR  phase  1 
proposals and the capacity building program for phase 1 for PNG and Tonga. 
(v)  Provide regular reports on phase 1 implementation in accordance with ADB and 
PPCR guidelines and requirements. 
 
B.  Climate Change Mainstreaming Specialist (international, 6 person-months over 9-
month period) 
 
6.  An international consultant will be engaged for 6 person-months over a 9-month period 
to work (both from home and in the field) with the national and international project team 
consultants and the ADB Pacific Climate Change Team to provide technical advice on climate 
change mainstreaming for the PPCR phase 1 program for the ADB components of the Pacific 
PPCR.  
 
7.  The consultant will be responsible for the delivery of vulnerability assessments of priority 
infrastructure  investments  in  PNG  and  Tonga  based  on  current  methodologies  and  the 
development of climate change adaptation mainstreaming products.  The consultancy requires 
the  development  of  strategic-level  climate  change  scenarios  in  each  country  (through  the 
interpretation of a Government of Australia funded high-resolution scenario project under the 
International  Climate  Change  Adaptation  Initiative),  and  a  selected  number  of  vulnerability 
assessments specified through the  consultative  process. The  specialist  will  be  required to 
provide related technical advice throughout the project. This consultancy will primarily work on 
two of the four Pacific PPCR components: (i) PNG; and (ii) Tonga, coordinating as necessary 
with the development of the region-wide activities component. The consultant will be required 
for the entire project duration and will contribute 6 person-months, including up to three visits to 
both PNG and Tonga. Extensive skills in climate change adaptation impact assessment and 
mainstreaming, as well as previous country experiences are required. 
 
8.  Specifically,  the  climate  change  mainstreaming  international  specialist  will  do  the 
following in PNG and Tonga: 
 
(i)  Develop  a  set  of  strategic-level  nationally  consistent,  reliable,  and  justifiable 
scientific scenarios of key climate change to ensure harmonization of climate 
change  resilience-building  across  sectors.  The  scenarios  will  be  developed 
through  local  interpretation  of  the  scenarios  generated  by  the  International 
Climate Change Adaptation Initiative, and relevant downscaling of regional and 
national vulnerability assessments and risks to infrastructure. 
(ii)  Assist in the identification of capacity constraints in key ministries and sector 
agencies to mainstreaming climate change in development, budgeting, design, 
and implementation of infrastructure investments as input to the capacity building 
program for phases 1 and 2.

(iii)  Based on the capacity building program for phase 1, assist in capacity building in 
key  ministries  responsible  for  provision  of  infrastructure,  to  integrate  climate 
change  resilience  in  budgetary  systems,  financial  allocations,  and  reporting 
mechanisms through short courses, workshops, and related training. 
(iv)  Develop national guidelines and a best practice manual for the integration of 
climate  change  factors  into  infrastructure  planning  including  where  relevant 
ecosystem adaption of catchments. 
(v)  Undertake  vulnerability  assessments,  using  available  methodologies  and 
processes, of an initial list of infrastructure projects that could be targeted in the 
PPCR phase 2. These will build on the proposed vulnerability and adaptation 
initiatives  targeted  by  development  partners  and  supported  by  regional 
assessment activities. 
(vi)  Provide  ongoing  advice  on  climate  change  adaptation  planning  and 
mainstreaming as required. 
(vii)  In close consultation with the team leader and other members of the consultant 
team, assist in drafting the SPCR, with investment proposals for climate-proofing 
of infrastructure projects in accordance with PPCR guidelines and a capacity 
building program for phases 1 and 2. 
 
C.  Civil Society Engagement Specialist (international, 3 person-months over 9-month 
period) 
 
9.  An international consultant will be engaged to work (both from home and in the field) 
with the national and international consultants and the ADB Pacific Climate Change Team to 
provide  specialist  advice  on  civil  society  engagement  for  the  PPCR  phase  1  of  the  ADB 
components of the Pacific PPCR.  
 
10.  The consultant will be responsible for the delivery of the capacity needs assessment for 
effective involvement of civil society in each country, gender integration requirements, and the 
drafting of specific information products targeted at civil society and the private sector as input 
to the capacity building program for phases 1 and 2.  The climate change adaptation experts in 
each country will provide the technical requirements for drafting of the information products. 
This consultancy will work primarily on two of the four Pacific PPCR components: (i) PNG, and 
(ii)  Tonga  coordinating  as  necessary  with  the  development  of  the  regionwide  activities 
component.   
 
11.  The consultancy will include up to three visits to both PNG and Tonga. Civil society and 
gender  mainstreaming  experience  is  required  and  information  engagement  product 
development skills are necessary. 
 
12.  Specifically, the civil society engagement specialist will do the following for PNG and 
Tonga: 
 
(i)  Undertake  a  capacity  needs  assessment  report,  including  specification  of 
approaches for effective involvement of civil society and the private sector in the 
PPCR, as input to the capacity building program for phases 1 and 2. 
(ii)  Develop information products targeted at civil  society and the private sector 
including,  possibly,  support  for  a  national  conference  on  climate  resilience 
building in the infrastructure sector in PNG. 
(iii)  Identify  and  operationalize  opportunities  for  civil  society  and  private  sector 
engagement in climate change adaptation.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(iv)  Develop  approaches  for  integrating  gender  concerns  into  climate  change 
adaptation  through  pilot  projects  to  undertake  sensitivity,  vulnerability,  and 
adaptation assessments (led by the international specialist in climate change 
mainstreaming). 
 
D.  Country Climate Change Mainstreaming Specialist (2 national, one for PNG and one 
for Tonga, over 9-month period) 
 
13.  Two national consultants (1 from PNG and 1 from Tonga) will be engaged to work with 
the  international  team  leader  and  international  specialists  on  climate  change  adaptation 
mainstreaming and civil society engagement, to provide specialist advice on mainstreaming 
climate change adaptation in key sectors of government (focused on infrastructure) and civil 
society engagement for the PPCR phase 1 of the ADB components of the Pacific PPCR. The 
national  consultants  will  act  as  focal  points  in  each  country,  and  work  closely  with  their 
international counterparts and all national stakeholders (government and nongovernment). 
 
14.  Specifically, the climate change mainstreaming specialists will do the following: 
 
(i)  Assist the international climate change adaptation mainstreaming specialist to 
ensure country localization of a set of strategic-level scientific scenarios of key 
climate  change  scenarios.  The  scenarios  will  be  developed  through  local 
interpretation of the scenarios generated by the International Climate Change 
Adaptation Initiative, among others.  
(ii)  Assist the international climate change adaptation mainstreaming specialist to 
draft national guidelines and best practices manual for the integration of climate 
change factors into infrastructure planning including ecosystem adaptation of 
catchments where relevant. 
(iii)  Assist the international climate change adaptation mainstreaming specialist to 
undertake vulnerability assessments of an initial list of infrastructure projects that 
could be targeted in the SPCR (PPCR phase 2).  
(iv)  Assist in the assessment of relevant cross-sector and sector legislation, policies, 
and  plans  of  key  ministries  and  agencies  responsible  for  provision  of 
infrastructure, for factoring in climate change resilience. 
(v)  Assist in the assessment of capacity constraints as input to capacity building 
program for phases 1 and 2, and assist in capacity building in key ministries 
responsible for provision of infrastructure, to integrate climate change resilience 
in budgetary systems, financial allocations, and reporting mechanisms, through 
short courses, workshops, and related trainings. 
(vi)  Provide  ongoing  advice  on  climate  change  adaptation  planning  and 
mainstreaming as required. 
(vii)  Assist the international civil society engagement specialist to draft a capacity 
needs  assessment  report  including  specification  of  approaches  for  effective 
involvement of civil society in the PPCR. 
(viii)  Assist the international civil society engagement specialist to develop targeted 
information products for civil society and the private sector. 
(ix)  Assist  the  international  civil  society  engagement  specialist  to  identify  and 
operationalize opportunities for private sector engagement in climate change 
adaptation. 
(x)  Assist  the  international  civil  society  engagement  specialist  to  develop 
approaches  for  integrating  gender  concerns  into  climate  change  adaptation 
through  pilot  projects  to  undertake  sensitivity,  vulnerability,  and  adaptation

Appendix 3  13 
 
assessments  (led  by  the  international  specialist  in  climate  change 
mainstreaming). 
  
E.  Web Developer (national, 1 person-month over 9-month period) 
 
15.  A national consultant will be engaged for 1 person-month over a 9-month period to work 
(from  ADB  headquarters)  with  the  international  and  national  consultants  and  ADB  Pacific 
Climate  Change  Team.  This  national  consultant  will  build  on  existing  regional  platforms 
(including of the Council of Regional Organizations in the Pacific such as the South Pacific 
Regional Environment Programme) to refine a web-based platform for the dissemination of 
information and knowledge products for the PPCR phase 1 on the ADB components of the 
Pacific PPCR. The web system will be required to build on, and not duplicate, existing regional 
platforms. 
 
16.  The web developer will be required to work closely with the international consultant team 
leader  to  develop  a  detailed  specification  for  the  platform,  in  line  with  ADB  information 
management requirements. This consultancy will work primarily on two of the four Pacific PPCR 
components: (i) PNG; and (ii) Tonga coordinating as necessary with the development of the 
region wide activities component. The consultant will be required for 1 person-month throughout 
the project with the bulk of effort anticipated about halfway through program implementation, 
depending on the detailed project plan. 
 
17.  Specifically, the web developer will do the following: 
 
(i)  Review  program  design  documentation  and  ensure  the  platform  design  is 
suitable for the type of products being developed. 
(ii)  Design  and  deliver  a  web-based  platform  that  builds  on  existing  regional 
platforms,  for  the  dissemination  of  information  and  knowledge  products, 
considering  ADB  and  country  information  management  requirements,  and 
technical requirements.
